title: Vulnerability & Safety
description: Explore how safe you feel being vulnerable with each other

questions.text: I can let my guard down when I'm with my partner.

therapeutic.rationale: Letting your guard down requires feeling safe. When you can relax your defenses with your partner, you create space for authentic connection and intimacy.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner can't let their guard down, explore what would help create safety. This is about the relationship environment, not a personal failing.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual ability to let guards down creates a foundation for deep intimacy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps you let your guard down with your partner? What keeps it up?

questions.text: I feel held with care when I'm vulnerable with my partner.

therapeutic.rationale: How vulnerability is received matters as much as whether it's offered. Partners who handle each other's vulnerable moments with care build trust for future openness.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel their vulnerability is handled with care, specific examples help. The other partner may not realize how their responses land.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual experience of careful handling of vulnerability creates a safe container for intimacy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you've been vulnerable with your partner, how have they responded?

questions.text: I don't worry about being judged when I'm open with my partner.

therapeutic.rationale: Fear of judgment closes us off. When you trust your partner won't judge your needs, desires, or body, you can be more fully present and open.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner fears judgment, explore what creates that fear. Past comments? Perceived reactions? Understanding the source helps address it.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared freedom from judgment fears creates an accepting environment for intimacy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would you be more open about if you knew you wouldn't be judged?

questions.text: Being vulnerable with my partner brings us closer.

therapeutic.rationale: Vulnerability that creates closeness reinforces itselfâ€”you take a risk, feel closer, and become more willing to risk again. When vulnerability doesn't lead to closeness, the cycle breaks.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If vulnerability doesn't create closeness for one partner, explore what happens instead. Does it create distance? Anxiety? Understanding the pattern helps.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared experience of vulnerability creating closeness is a powerful relationship strength.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Think of a time being vulnerable brought you closer. What made that possible?

questions.text: I feel my partner trusts me with their vulnerability too.

therapeutic.rationale: Mutual vulnerability creates balance. When only one partner is vulnerable, the relationship can feel one-sided. Sensing your partner's trust to be vulnerable with you is connecting.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel trusted with the other's vulnerability, explore what would help. Some people show vulnerability differently than others expect.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual trust to be vulnerable with each other creates reciprocal intimacy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner show they trust you with their vulnerable side?
